summary: The document is a confidential report from 1964, detailing intelligence information about Julian NOVAS Fernandez, a Cuban intelligence officer. It includes observations from a source within the Cuban Intelligence Service, noting NOVAS's assignment as a Commercial Attache in Kingston, Jamaica, his movements, and personal details. The report also highlights suspicions regarding his role as the new Cuban Intelligence Service chief in Jamaica, based on his salary and allowances, and mentions the arrival of his wife, Amarilis Hicrta VALDES Hijuelos, in Kingston with a diplomatic passport.
key_findings: Julian NOVAS Fernandez was identified as a Cuban intelligence officer by a source within the Cuban Intelligence Service.
NOVAS was assigned to the Cuban Consulate in Kingston, Jamaica, as a Commercial Attache, with records suggesting his presence in Mexico City in March 1964 was merely transitional.
NOVAS possesses an American appearance and speaks excellent English, with a noted interest in social interactions.
Amarilis Hicrta VALDES Hijuelos, NOVAS's wife, arrived in Kingston in April 1964, carrying a diplomatic passport.
Suspicions arose that NOVAS might be the new Cuban Intelligence Service chief in Jamaica, inferred from his salary and allowances.
